email_chain.subject: Freight Inquiry for Crude Oil Shipment
email_chain.body: Hi John, I hope this email finds you well. I’m reaching out regarding your inquiry for a crude oil shipment from Houston to Rotterdam. We have a suitable vessel, the MV Ocean Star, with a DWT of 150,000 and LOA of 280m. The laycan is 15-20 October. The starting freight rate is in the low 50s, say $50.75 per metric ton. Let me know your thoughts. Best regards, Sarah.

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry for Crude Oil Shipment
email_chain.body: Hi Sarah, thanks for the quick response. The laycan works for us, but the freight rate seems a bit high. We were hoping for something closer to $49.50 per metric ton. Also, could you confirm the demurrage rate? Looking forward to your reply. Cheers, John.

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry for Crude Oil Shipment
email_chain.body: Hi John, thanks for your feedback. I understand your concern about the rate. After discussing with the owner, we can offer $50.00 per metric ton, which is a competitive rate given the current market. The demurrage rate is $20,000 per day pro rata. Let me know if this works for you. Best, Sarah.

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry for Crude Oil Shipment
email_chain.body: Hi Sarah, thanks for the revised offer. We can agree to $50.00 per metric ton, provided the laycan remains firm at 15-20 October. Also, could you confirm the vessel’s readiness and any additional terms? Best, John.

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry for Crude Oil Shipment
email_chain.body: Hi John, great to hear that the rate works for you. The MV Ocean Star is currently in Houston and will be ready for loading as per the agreed laycan. I’ll send over the charter party agreement shortly for your review. Let me know if there’s anything else you need. Best regards, Sarah.

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry for Crude Oil Shipment
email_chain.body: Hi Sarah, sounds good. Please proceed with the charter party agreement, and we’ll review it promptly. Looking forward to finalizing this shipment. Thanks, John.
